block.p: Newspaper Chain on Block As Another Sells 38 Papers Central Newspapers, which owns The Arizona Republic, The Indianapolis Star and four other newspapers, announced that it was putting itself up for sale. The move would take another multigenerational newspaper family, the Pulliams, out of the business. Shares of Central Newspapers rose $20.50, to $52.

Newspaper Chain on Block As Another Sells 38 Papers Central Newspapers, which owns The Arizona Republic, The Indianapolis Star and four other newspapers, announced that it was putting itself up for sale. The move would take another multigenerational newspaper family, the Pulliams, out of the business. Shares of Central Newspapers rose $20.50, to $52.

A few hours later, Gannett and Community Newspaper Holdings said they were acquiring 38 of the 49 newspapers Thomson had put on the block. Gannett is paying $1.13 billion for 21 newspapers. Community Newspaper Holdings is buying 17 papers for $455 million. The sale of the remaining 11 daily newspapers Thomson wants to sell is expected to be completed within days. [Page C2.]

Anatomy of Microsoft Court Defeat Dozens of state and federal officials who have investigated and prosecuted Microsoft for the last four years, as well as industry executives, have seen many moves by Microsoft that they think backfired and led to a resounding court defeat in the company's antitrust case. [A1.]

National Semiconductor Profit Up National Semiconductor reported fourth-quarter earnings that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates as sales increased 22.5 percent. And executives raised their predictions for revenue growth in the next fiscal year to about 30 percent from 25 percent. [C3.]

Stocks Fall Ahead of Economic Data Stocks fell as investors pulled back before important economic data scheduled to be released today. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 144.14 points, or 1.3 percent, to 10,668.72. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 13.70 points, or 0.4 percent, to 3,825.56, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 9.69 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,461.67. [C11.]

Interest Rates Increased in Europe The European Central Bank raised its core interest rate half a percentage point, to 4.25 percent, in an unexpectedly aggressive attempt to help insulate Europe against inflation. The move surprised most economists and sent currency traders into a confused frenzy over the euro, which rose and then slipped back. [C4.]

'Survivor' Extends Its Hit Status Establishing its credentials as the runaway television hit of the summer, the CBS show ''Survivor,'' which chronicles the adventures of 16 real people coexisting on an island off Borneo, scored extraordinary ratings for the second consecutive week, this time even drubbing ABC's ''Who Wants To Be A Millionaire,'' in every audience category. More than 18 million people watched the show Wednesday night, when B. B. Andersen was voted off the island by other cast members. [C2.]

Another Soros Executive to Quit The last of three top money managers announced his departure from the dwindling empire of George Soros. Scott Bessent, who oversees European investments for Soros Fund Management, said he would leave to start a private investment group. [C3.]

May Prices for Imported Goods Fell The prices businesses pay for imported goods, excluding petroleum, fell 0.2 percent in May, the first time in almost a year, government figures showed, suggesting that inexpensive imports are helping to contain inflation. [C22.]

Campaign That Looks Out for No. 1 The recently formed MarchFirst, which offers a variety of Internet professional services, hopes to stand out among competitors ranging from management consultants to advertising agencies to Web site builders through an extensive -- and expensive -- ad campaign centered on a celebration of being, well, first. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]
